title: Emergency Survival Kit: Supplies to Pack for Any Disaster
post_description: When a hurricane the size of Sandy or Michael slams into the coast, it leaves turmoil in its wake. Families stranded in its aftermath may wait days or even weeks for relief to come while government resources focus on rescuing those trapped or injured by the storm.

title: 5 Indispensable Tools for Homesteading
post_description: My wife and I began our off-grid lifestyle with an assortment of basic hand tools for construction, gardening, and the general repair tasks of a small homestead. We picked most of them up at flea markets, and were given some antique planes and handsaws (which we still use today) from an old collector. The only big purchase we made was a chainsaw, a tool I don’t think we could have managed without.

title: Solar Food Dehydration: How to Sun Dry Your Food
post_description: Every morning the sun rises, showering the earth with invisible photons, warming our planet, and feeding our plants with energy. To me, this last process is magical: the earth’s vegetation collects and stores the sun’s energy, combining it with carbon dioxide and water to create the absolute necessity of life—food. It’s no wonder that all over the world, people start their day with sun salutations.

title: Our Simple DIY Home Solar Power System
post_description: Bringing some of the benefits of electrical power to our off-grid home has been a hit-or-miss affair. Over the years we’ve tried some very simple approaches to lighting and small battery recharging for our flashlights, such as hauling a 12 volt car battery to a small rural school about a half mile away every time it needed to be topped up. This was time consuming and inefficient.

title: This Gift is Saving Lives in Puerto Rico
post_description:
While most Americans are getting ready for the holiday season, Puerto Ricans are still struggling to resume normal life three months after a deadly hurricane struck the island. 
According to PBS, 93% of Puerto Ricans now have some access to clean water following Hurricane Maria, though ‘access’ doesn’t necessarily mean that water is running from the taps.

title: How to Survive a Week Without Running Water
post_description: The average American uses approximately 80 - 100 gallons of water per day, with the largest percentage of that being flushed down the toilet. Our consumption is one of the highest in the world, even when compared to other first world countries, such as Great Britain, where the average person uses about 40 gallons per day.

title: Emergency Power Supply: Are You Ready for the Next Major Power Outage?
post_description: Scientists expect the pace and intensity of natural disasters influenced by our changing climate to increase. Alternative energy sources can help you weather the storm.

title: 8 Ways to Help the Victims of Hurricane Harvey
post_description: With more than 33 Texan counties ravaged by floodwaters and 30,000 people displaced, victims of Hurricane Harvey urgently need help. The hurricane, which was downgraded to a tropical storm after ravaging Texas with historic rainfall followed by floods, made landfall in Louisiana on Wednesday.

title: Earthquake Preparedness: How to Prepare for the ‘Big One’
post_description:
In theory, those who are at home when it hits should be safest; it is easy and relatively inexpensive to seismically safeguard a private dwelling. But, lulled into nonchalance by their seemingly benign environment, most people in the Pacific Northwest have not done so.</br>
—Kathryn Schultz, from “The Really Big One"

title: 7 Preparedness Tips for Unexpected Power Outages
post_description: Well, it is that time of year again. Thanksgiving is a heartbeat away and Christmas is right around the corner. Aside from being great holidays, they are markers that winter is a moment away. Sometimes it is hard to remember that with the holidays so close, the soon to be frigid temperatures will bring more than good cheer.

title: Our DIY Off-Grid Fire Protection System
post_description: Fire protection in remote areas is largely a do-it-yourself affair. With no road to our place, the small volunteer fire department couldn’t get here to help, and with only a few neighbors we would have little help to draw upon in a fire emergency. But with so much else to do when building a homestead, and with limited finances, fire protection always seemed lower on the list of things to do.

title: Water Filtration for Emergency Preparedness
post_description: It’s a topic many of us would rather avoid.  With climate change news worsening, and dire speculations increasingly credible, it’s natural to feel like changing the channel.  Extreme weather events are popping up in all kinds of formerly peaceful areas.

title: How to Live Out Of Your Car
post_description: As the old song says, there but for fortune go you or go I… and sometimes fortunes change swiftly. None of us are immune from the twists and turns of fate. When you lose the roof over your head, keep your wits (and your wheels) about you.

title: Teaching My Child First Aid: 6 Essentials
post_description: Thinking and talking about potential worst-case-scenarios often happens when the kids are asleep or at school. We want to protect our children from fears and allow them to “just be kids,” playing and growing, trusting us to keep everything scary at bay.

title: Is Your Pet Prepared for a Major Storm or Evacuation?
post_description: Hurricanes, wildfires, floods, tsunamis, oil spills: catastrophes are in the news and on our minds. Are you ready? Public agencies and reporters stress creating disaster plans for your family, but animals are often left out of the equation. Before Hurricane Katrina, FEMA disaster simulations excluded pets. One researcher explained "They were not part of our plans because they </br>are not considered to be important.”

title: 6 Beginner Recipes for Solar Ovens
post_description: What can you cook in your solar oven? Just about anything: bake, boil, steam, stew, and even dehydrate! (OK, skip the fried foods — you'll feel better not eating those greasy meals anyway.) It’s a wonderful feeling producing a hot, nourishing meal using nothing but</br> the sun’s life-giving rays.

title: Harvesting Rainwater for Residential Water Security
post_description: We had been drinking water from our rural well for about two years when we decided to have it tested. It turned out that our water had 300 times the iron recommended for human use.  That sent us to our roof and the collection of rainwater for our potable water source.

title: 5 Tips for Tornado Preparedness
post_description: Few natural occurrences have the ability to inspire dread in quite the same way as the tornado. The way it descends out of the heavens like a vengeful god; the sheer awe-inspiring destructive power it contains; it touches upon something primal and instinctual in the human soul. We may have eliminated all of our natural predators thousands of years ago, but the tornado still makes us feel like helpless prey.

title: How to Keep your Cell Phone Working During a Power Outage
post_description: When the power goes out during a storm, we rely more on our cell phones and smart phones to stay in touch with emergency responders, neighbors and relatives. Unfortunately, without a backup charging system, portable phones and mobile devices can be useless just when we need them the most.

title: What it’s Like Raising Children Off-Grid
post_description: When my wife and I decided to move to a remote off-grid location, our biggest concern centered around child rearing. We were young and idealistic, and felt up to the challenges ahead, but we were also new parents of a 3-month old baby.

title: How to Make a Simple ‘Ready-Kit’ for Your Daypack
post_description: Emergencies have a way of arriving at unexpected moments, and outdoor enthusiasts can encounter difficulties even during casual day activities. A skier may find himself out of bounds and disoriented after taking a wrong turn during limited visibility conditions. A routine day hike can go wrong with an injury, a sudden weather change, or simply taking the wrong path. A sports fisherman may follow a winding stream one turn too far and have difficulty returning before dark.

title: Sharks, Misunderstood and Maligned, Need Marine Sanctuaries
post_description: A diver was killed by a great white in Australia last week. You’ve probably heard of the attack, it was covered in all the major news outlets. This was the third fatal shark attack off the west coast of Australia in two months.

title: Contaminated Drinking Water Feared in Hurricane’s Wake
post_description: As Hurricane Irene etched its ragged course through the Northeast recently, residents were somewhat relieved that the wind strength had abated enough to spare widespread structural damage. Visions of a sea of broken glass in New York were fortunately not realized, wave damage to coastal Long Island was less than feared, and damage from windfall trees, while significant, could have been much worse.

title: How to Prepare for a Heat Wave
post_description: The heat wave currently settling across much of the country is distressing on several levels. The heat index today is as high as 126 degrees in portions of the upper Midwest, which is bad enough, but it also underscores what climatologists have long been predicting: we will likely be seeing more heat waves than usual as the planet warms.

title: Using Vegetable Oil to Replace Chainsaw Oil
post_description: Every time I fill my chain saw with oil for lubricating the bar and chain, I realize that 100% of this petroleum-based oil will be sprayed into the environment. The modern chainsaw’s “total loss lubricating system” releases the oil from the bar tip once it has travelled around the bar a few times, and the atomized oil particles cling to the sawdust or spray over the work area. When a chain saw is used, virtually all of the lubricant ends up in the environment.

title: How to Prepare Your Home & Protect the Environment Against Natural Emergencies
post_description: Environmental hazards come in many forms, from local mishaps such as a tree falling on your roof or a flooded basement during heavy rain, to large scale natural disasters such as wildfires, earthquakes, tornadoes and hurricanes.

title: Water Storage Tips
post_description: Some preparedness authorities recommend storing at least 14 gallons of water per person, which amounts to a two-week supply. But water stored improperly can be hazardous to health. Here are some basic tips for storing water safely over extended periods of time.

title: Transition Towns – preparing for a self-sufficient community-based future
post_description: While leaders in all levels of government discuss the realities of global economic distress, uncertain future energy supplies, and the overarching threat of climate change, a quiet evolution is making real progress in developing strategies to help us transform our communities to adapt to these upcoming challenges.

title: Our Experience With a Solar Powered Refrigerator
post_description: I admit to being something of a Luddite. It’s not that I dislike technology, it’s just my feeling that many modern ‘conveniences’ and technological marvels can get in the way of enjoying the simple pleasures of living in a beautiful natural environment. And so my wife and I chose to live in a rural “off-grid” community and raise our two children in this setting.

title: What It's Like Living Off-Grid
post_description: We bought a small cabin with land on a rural island in the Pacific Northwest. Since there were no services to the island, our home had no electricity. Residents of the island had to create their own electricity or do without.

title: Tips for Installing a Rainwater Collection System
post_description: Homeowners can conserve water both indoors and outdoors by adopting simple conservation strategies, but many people overlook the opportunity of collecting and storing rainwater for use in the yard, garden and outdoor cleaning projects.
